title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: cohort, first estimate age pattern increase proportion ever-smokers. done function smktrans::init_est() - can see help file typing ?init_est. function takes self-reported age cigarettes first smoked constructs vector 0s, 1s NAs corresponding age individual (1 = initiated smoking, NA = censored). constructed variable age cigarettes first smoked HSE using hseclean R package (see hseclean::smk_life_history()). smktrans::init_est() function first calculates cohort strata specific mean 0s 1s - gives estimate probability someone cohort strata initiated smoking age. function calculates cumulative probability starting smoke age. HSE data function applied cleaned advance using smktrans. cumulative probabilities ever-smoking estimated
code: # Calculate the cumulative probabilities of starting to smoke for each cohort init_data_raw <- smktrans::init_est(   data = hse_data,   strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile") )

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: main problem estimates don‚Äôt correspond proportions ever-smokers ascertained asking respondents directly ever smoked cigarettes regularly (due range factors e.g.¬†recall bias selective mortality). Developing method used Holford et al. (2014), estimated applied adjustment factor make estimates correspond. first step estimation adjustment factor estimate proportions ever-smokers certain index age question asks directly ever-smoking. done function smktrans::ever_smoke(). function uses survey::svyglm estimate expected proportions ever-smokers accounting survey weights survey sampling design. filter data ages 25-34 years, stratify summary cohort, sex IMD quintile. function fits survey weighted linear regression (quasibinomial) trends, allows extrapolation future cohorts. next step estimate adjustment factor apply adjustment. done function smktrans::init_adj(). function assigns reference age cohort (default 30 years). adjustment factor calculated cohort strata applied make adjustment. Finally, use function smktrans::p_dense() convert probabilities ever-smoking (cumulative density function) probabilities initiating smoking age. modelling smoking dynamics, want initiation probabilities ages 30 years (assume new initiation) period modelled 2001 onwards.
code: # Estimate the trend in the proportion of people who have ever smoked # in the age range 25-34 ever_smoke_data <- smktrans::ever_smoke(   data = hse_data,   time_horizon = 2200,   num_bins = 7,   model = "England" ) # Adjust and forecast init_data_adj <- init_adj(   init_data = copy(init_data_raw),   ever_smoke_data = copy(ever_smoke_data$predicted_values),   ref_age = 30,   cohorts = 1971:2100,   period_start = 2001, period_end = 2016) smk_init_data <- p_dense(data = copy(init_data_adj), cum_func_var = "p_ever_smoker_adj",                      strat_vars = c("cohort", "sex", "imd_quintile"))

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: consider probability relapse smoking former smokers 1 10 years since quitting, call long-term relapse. estimate probabilities, combine published estimates long-term relapse Hawkins et al. (2010) Health Survey England data. function smktrans::prep_relapse(). Hawkin‚Äôs statistical analysis adjusts several covariates. adjust subset covariates detailed : age - continuous function sex time since quit - 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6+ years degree employed married, cohabiting neither mental health condition income - mapped Hawkins income quartiles equivalised income quintiles HSE pooling lowest two income quintiles. Note Hawkins found physical health / GP visits also explained statistically significant variation smoking relapse able adjust due lack corresponding variables Health Survey England. first step assign former smoker HSE expected probability relapse based matching time since quit covariates . second step calculate weighted averages relapse probability subgroups defined either age, sex IMD quintile (feed estimation quit probabilities) age, sex, IMD quintile time since quit (feed simulation individual smoking histories).
code: # Combine published estimates of long-term relapse with the Health Survey for England data to arrive at the expected values for relapse probabilities within defined subgroups. relapse_data <- smktrans::prep_relapse(   data = hse_data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse,   lowest_year = 2001,   highest_year = 2016,   youngest_age = 11 )

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: age-specific probabilities smoker quit smoking complex estimate due number potential biases. formula derived (see accompanying article) uses probabilities initiation relapse. also uses following inputs:

what: Proportions of current, former and never smokers
title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: statistically smooth HSE trends age year proportions current, former never smokers, using function smktrans::trend_fit(). fits multinomial linear model distribution people among current, former never smoking status, model estimates variation trends sex socioeconomic conditions terms quintiles Index Multiple Deprivation. model logit link function accounts HSE survey weights. Age year converted z-scores (subtracting mean dividing twice standard deviation) model fitting. explanatory variables age aa year yy specified form cubic response surface, form +a2+y+y2+ay+a3+y3+a2y+ay2a+^2+y+y^2+ay + ^3 + y^3+^2y+ay^2. added additional 4th order term age a4a^4 better capture non-linear patterns age e.g.¬†individuals initiate quit age. Interactions surface sex IMD quintiles limited 3rd order terms. Interactions quadratic term included age year avoid -fitting variation trend years, linear change pattern age. decision made visually exploring fit simpler complex model specifications data.
code: # model trends in current, former and never smoking trend_data <- smktrans::trend_fit(hse_data,   max_iterations = 1e3,   age_var = "age",   year_var = "year",   sex_var = "sex",   smoker_state_var = "smk.state",   imd_var = "imd_quintile",   weight_var = "wt_int")

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: approximating number individuals alive age within cohort cohort survivorship function, probability individual survive start age interval. get data right format function smktrans::prep_surv(). function smktrans::prep_surv() calculates cohort survivorship function age, .e.¬†probability someone cohort survive start 1 year age interval, stratified sex IMD quintile. function takes two data sources inputs: Data 1922 Human Mortality Database 1x1 age period central death rates (mx) England & Wales civilian population. Death rates stratified sex . use HMD data estimate sex-specific survivorship curves age 12 onwards cohort features 2001-2016 window. Death rates 2001-2016 England age, sex, year IMD quintile. data produced Office National Statistics (ONS) mortality microdata (processing data done mort.tools R package data stored virtual machine). use ONS data inform differences IMD quintile age- sex-specific probabilities surviving 1 year age interval years 2001-2016. smktrans::prep_surv() calculates survivorship curves partially stratified IMD quintile (use data IMD quintile differences survival 2001). partial stratification sufficient calculation formula uses ratios people alive age +1a+1 compared age aa, .e.¬†important thing reliably characterised shapes survivorship functions 2001 2016 cohort, sex IMD quintile.
code: # Estimate the shape of the cohort survivorship functions survivorship_data <- smktrans::prep_surv(   mx_data_hmd = smktrans::hmd_data,   mx_data_ons = smktrans::tob_mort_data )

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: estimated age-specific probabilities surviving age aa age +1a+1, stratified sex, IMD quintile smoking status (current, former, never regular cigarette smoker). estimates used adjust probability quitting smoking mortality differentials smoking status. estimation survival smoking status done function smktrans::smoke_surv(). use individually-linked data smoking status linked time death. Instead, infer mortality differentials smoking status based relative differences risks smoking-related diseases among current, former never smokers. make calculations, smktrans::smoke_surv() calls functions tobalcepi::RRFunc() stapmr::SurvFunc(). Data relative risks disease smoking status rates death smoking-related disease also taken data stored packages. tobalcepi::RRFunc() assigns relative risk disease based whether individual current, former never smoker. current smokers relative risk regardless amount currently smoke smoked past. Former smokers initially given relative risk associated current smokers, scale according disease-specific function describes risk declines quitting smoking. stapmr::SurvFunc() computes individual probability death based individual‚Äôs relative risks disease mortality rates disease sex IMD quintile subgroup. result individual specific mortality rates average subgroup rate. mortality rates converted probability death one-year age interval exponentially age-interval. Probabilities death summed across causes give overall probability death. smktrans::smoke_surv() takes estimated probabilities death fits smooth line age pattern year, sex, IMD quintile smoking status. values smoothed fit converted probabilities surviving age aa age +1a+1, stratified sex, IMD quintile smoking status.
code: # Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status mortality_data <- smktrans::smoke_surv(   data = hse_data,   diseases  = unique(tobalcepi::tobacco_relative_risks$condition),   mx_data = stapmr::tob_mort_data_cause )

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: Quit probabilities calculated function smktrans::quit_est(), applies equation derived (see article) using parameter estimates . result probabilities quitting smoking stratified single years age (11-88) period (2001-2015), sex IMD quintile.
code: # Calculate quit probabilities quit_data <- quit_est(   dataq = hse_data,   trend_dataq = trend_data,   survivorship_dataq = survivorship_data,   mortality_dataq = mortality_data$data_for_quit_ests,   relapse_dataq = relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd,   initiation_dataq = smk_init_data,   lowest_yearq = 2001,   highest_yearq = 2016,   youngest_yearq = 11 )

title: Workflow: Smoking state transition probability estimation
text: function smktrans::quit_forecast() applied separately sex IMD quintile. first smooths pattern quit probabilities (2-dimensional moving average, values considered form 7-year-square single years age period). well smoothing trends, also acts fill-missing values based information neighbouring values age period. fill-remaining missing values approximating age-specific trend periods. Second, function forecasts trend quit probabilities based singular value decomposition (logit transformed probabilities). produces single vector describe trend period, project forwards based fit linear model data selected year onwards (first_year). decomposition also estimates age-emphasis change .e.¬†whether change relatively fasters young old ages - fit linear slope age-pattern change. forecast based recombining two components predict trend future years. smktrans::quit_forecast() options adjust reference years time horizon. also option specify future year continuing trend quit probabilities switches continuing stationary (case want use function play forecast scenario, might easily done outside function).
code: forecast_data <- quit_forecast(   data = copy(quit_data),   forecast_var = "p_quit",   forecast_type = "continuing", # continuing or stationary   cont_limit = 2030, # the year at which the forecast becomes stationary   first_year = 2007, # the earliest year of data on which the forecast is based   jump_off_year = 2015,   time_horizon = 2030 )

what: An R Package and Workflow for estimating smoking state transition probabilities
title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: ‚Äî

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: smktrans research compendium structured R package. serves two distinct purposes: 1. Toolbox: provides set R functions estimate transition probabilities among current, former, never smoking states (initiation, quitting, relapse) repeat cross-sectional survey data. 2. Workflow: contains specific analytical workflow used produce official estimates Sheffield Tobacco Policy Model (STPM). package part Sheffield Tobacco Alcohol Policy Modelling (STAPM) platform developed School Health Related Research University Sheffield.

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: smktrans can installed used like standard R package, designed encompass tools analysis. estimates produced workflow probabilities smoking initiation, quitting, relapse, stratified : * Age * Period * Sex * Index Multiple Deprivation (IMD) quintiles

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: workflow used produce estimates, including slides plots trends England Scotland, can found repository : üìÇ transition_probability_estimates

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: made code open source ensure transparency, share methodology, allow others utilize pre-calculated estimates. * England Estimates: Download via OSF * Scotland Estimates: Download via OSF * Wales Estimates: [Placeholder: Estimates Wales currently development linked available.]

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
text: smktrans relies several internal STAPM packages (hseclean, tobalcepi, mort.tools). can install package directly GitHub. University Sheffield managed computer, recommend installing Rtools via installr package first.
code: # install.packages("devtools")  # 1. Install dependencies devtools::install_git("[https://github.com/stapm/hseclean.git](https://github.com/stapm/hseclean.git)", build_vignettes = FALSE, quiet = TRUE) devtools::install_git("[https://github.com/stapm/tobalcepi.git](https://github.com/stapm/tobalcepi.git)", build_vignettes = FALSE, quiet = TRUE) devtools::install_git("[https://github.com/stapm/mort.tools.git](https://github.com/stapm/mort.tools.git)", build_vignettes = FALSE, quiet = TRUE)  # 2. Install smktrans devtools::install_git("[https://github.com/stapm-platform/smktrans.git](https://github.com/stapm-platform/smktrans.git)", build_vignettes = FALSE, quiet = TRUE)  # Note: You can add ref = "x.x.x" to any of the above to install a specific version.

title: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data
code: library(smktrans) library(tobalcepi) library(hseclean) library(mort.tools)  # Other useful packages for the workflow library(data.table) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)

title: Bin numeric variable ‚Äî bin_var
text: Converts numeric variable bins specified number, binned variable also numeric mid-points bins.

title: Bin numeric variable ‚Äî bin_var
code: bin_var(x, n_bins)

title: Bin numeric variable ‚Äî bin_var
text: x Numeric variable binned n_bins Integer - number bins create

title: Bin numeric variable ‚Äî bin_var
text: Returns numeric binned variable

title: Bin numeric variable ‚Äî bin_var

what: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
text: Calculates expected proportion ever-smokers, fits linear trend time proportion people ever smoked age category 25-34 years.

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
code: ever_smoke(   data,   time_horizon = 2100,   num_bins = 7,   model = c("model1", "model2", "model3", "model4", "model5")[1],   min_age = 15,   min_year = c(2003, 2008)[1] )

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
text: data Data table individual characteristics. time_horizon Integer - last year generate predictions ever-smoking index age. num_bins Integer - number bins create continuous period (year) variable. Wider bins = fewer data points estimate period trend, less random uncertainty data point. model Character - c("model1", "model2", "model3", "model4"). Model 1 - two-way interactions year trend sex IMD quintile. Model 2 - two-way interaction year trend sex . Model 3 - two-way interaction year trend IMD quintile . Model 4 - two-way interactions year trend either sex IMD quintile. min_age Integer - youngest age prediction progression ever-smoking cohort generated. Defaults 15 years. min_year Integer - first year survey data. England 2003 Scotland 2008.

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
text: Returns two data tables: "data_points", proportions ever-smokers age 25 observed survey data; "predicted_values", model predictions time horizon.

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
text: Uses 'survey' package fit model trends ever-smoking accounts survey sampling error survey design. linear model fitted binary response variable, 1 = ever smoker, 0 = never smoker estimates variation trend sex quintiles Index Multiple Deprivation. fitted model used predict / extrapolate trend year specified 'time horizon'.

title: Summarise and project trends in ever-smoking ‚Äî ever_smoke
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  test_data_trend <- ever_smoke(data = hse_data)  } # }

title: Long-term probabilities of smoking relapse ‚Äî hawkins_relapse
text: Hawkins J, Hollingworth W, Campbell R (2010). ‚ÄúLong-term smoking relapse: study using british household panel survey.‚Äù Nicotine & tobacco research, 12(12), 1228‚Äì1235.

title: Death rates for England & Wales ‚Äî hmd_data_eng

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
text: Takes probabilities ever-smoking estimated respondent recall adjusts according reported proportions ever-smokers reference age.

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
code: init_adj(   init_data,   ever_smoke_data,   ref_age = 30,   cohorts = 1973:2020,   period_start = 2003,   period_end = 2018 )

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
text: init_data Data table - raw estimates probabilities ever-smoking age, sex IMD quintile. ever_smoke_data Data table - reference values proportion ever-smokers. ref_age Integer - index age calibration cohorts Integer vector - cohorts adjusted. min cohort might sensibly period_start - ref_age, max cohort might baseline year model e.g. 2020. period_start Integer - first year data (England - 2003, Scotland - 2008) period_end Integer - last year data

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
text: Returns updated version init_data new variable containing adjusted values probabilities ever smoking. data also filtered include cohorts possible make adjustment.

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
text: based method applied Holford et al. (2014) .

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
text: Holford TR, Levy DT, McKay LA, Clarke L, Racine B, Meza R, Land S, Jeon J, Feuer EJ (2014). ‚ÄúPatterns birth cohort‚Äìspecific smoking histories, 1965‚Äì2009.‚Äù American journal preventive medicine, 46(2), e31‚Äìe37.

title: Adjust probabilities of ever-smoking ‚Äî init_adj
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # Estimate the raw probabilities of ever-smoking init_data_raw <- init_est(   data = hse_data,   strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile") )  # Estimate the reference values - observed proportions of ever-smokers ever_smoke_data <- ever_smoke(   data = hse_data,   time_horizon = 2100 )  # Adjust the probabilities of ever-smoking init_data_adj <- init_adj(   init_data = copy(init_data_raw),   ever_smoke_data = copy(ever_smoke_data$predicted_values),   ref_age = 30,   cohorts = 1971:2020, # 50 cohorts   period_start = 2001,   period_end = 2016 )   } # }

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
text: Calculate age-specific probabilities cumulative probabilities starting smoke cigarettes regularly based self-reported smoking histories.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
code: init_est(data, strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile"))

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
text: data Data table individual characteristics. strat_vars Character vector - variables stratify cohort estimates e.g. sex /IMD quintile.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
text: Returns data table containing age-specific probabilities cumulative probabilities starting smoke, ever never smoker.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
text: Takes self-reported age cigarettes first smoked regularly constructs vector 0s, 1s NAs corresponding age individual. 1 = initiated smoking, NA = censored.

title: Cohort specific smoking initiation ‚Äî init_est
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  test_data <- init_est(data = hse_data)  } # }

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
text: Combines published estimates long-term relapse population survey data arrive expected values relapse probabilities within defined subgroups.

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
code: prep_relapse(   data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse,   lowest_year = 2003,   highest_year = 2018,   youngest_age = 18 )

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
text: data Data table containing individual characteristics population survey data. hawkins_relapse Data table containing tidied version estimates long-term smoking relapse probability  Hawkins et al. (2010) . lowest_year integer - lowest year data available (England 2003 Scotland 2008). Default 2003. highest_year integer - highest year data available. youngest_age integer - youngest age data (England 11, Scotland 16).

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
text: Returns two data tables: First, relapse probabilities stratified year, age, IMD quintile time since quit (use STAPM simulation);  Second, relapse probabilities stratified just year, age IMD  quintile (use transition prob estimation).

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
text: function takes estimates relapse smoking Hawkins et al. (2010)  processes probabilities relapse smoking significant variables paper (age, time since quit, degree , mental health condition , married ). Note physical health / gp visits also significant included partly surveys right variables . mapped relapse probabilities onto survey data variables,  can calculate variation expected probability relapse age, sex, time since quit IMD quintile.

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
text: Hawkins J, Hollingworth W, Campbell R (2010). ‚ÄúLong-term smoking relapse: study using british household panel survey.‚Äù Nicotine & tobacco research, 12(12), 1228‚Äì1235.

title: Prepare long-term relapse probabilities ‚Äî prep_relapse
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test_data <- prep_relapse(   data = hse_data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse ) } # }

what: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship ‚Äî prep_surv
title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship ‚Äî prep_surv
text: Takes mortality rates birth since 1922 combines socioeconomically stratified mortality data period investigation produce estimate socioeconomic differences cohort survivorship.

title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship ‚Äî prep_surv
code: prep_surv(   mx_data_hmd = smktrans::hmd_data_eng,   mx_data_ons,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship ‚Äî prep_surv
text: mx_data_hmd Data table containing mortality rates 1922 Human Mortality Database. mx_data_ons Data table containing socioeconomically stratified mortality rates - process mortality data. min_age Integer - youngest age considered. max_age Integer - oldest age considered. min_year Integer - earliest year observed data. max_year Integer - latest year observed data.

title: Estimate socioeconomic differences in cohort survivorship ‚Äî prep_surv
text: Returns data table containing socioeconomically stratified cohort survivorship functions. Note data stratified IMD quintile year ages years needed estimation smoking state transition probabilities.

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test_data <- prep_surv(   mx_data_hmd = smktrans::hmd_data_eng,   mx_data_ons = tob_mort_data ) } # }

what: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
text: Converts cumulative density function probability density function, assuming interval 1.

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
code: p_dense(   data,   cum_func_var,   strat_vars = c("cohort", "sex", "imd_quintile"),   lowest_year = 2003,   max_year = 2100 )

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
text: data Data table containing estimates cumulative probabilities ever-smoking age. cum_func_var Character - name variable containing cumulative probabilities. strat_vars Character vector - variables stratify calculation. lowest_year integer - lowest year data available (England 2003 Scotland 2008). Default set 2003, HSE. max_year integer - latest year considered data + forecast

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
text: Returns updated version data new variable age-specific probabilities smoking initiation.

title: Convert probabilities of ever-smoking to age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation ‚Äî p_dense
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  init_data <- p_dense(data = copy(init_data_adj), cum_func_var = "p_ever_smoker_adj",                     strat_vars = c("cohort", "sex", "imd_quintile"))  } # }

what: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
text: Applies 2D moving average smooth trends age period, fills remaining missing values approximating age pattern within particular year.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
code: p_smooth(data, value_var, window_size = 3)

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
text: data Data table containing "age", "year" variable bounded 0 1. value_var Character - name variable smoothed. window_size - Integer - must odd number - number years covered moving average window.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
text: Returns data table data smoothed probability values.

title: Smooth age and period pattern in probability values ‚Äî p_smooth
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test_data <- data.frame(expand.grid(age = c(12:40, 42:89), year = 2001:2016)) setDT(test_data) test_data[ , prob := runif(nrow(test_data))] test_data[sample(1:nrow(test_data), 100, replace = F), prob := NA]  data_sm <- p_smooth(test_data, "prob", 3) } # }

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities ‚Äî quit_est
text: Combines various inputs together estimate smoking quit probabilities according formula given.

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities ‚Äî quit_est
code: quit_est(   trend_data,   survivorship_data,   mortality_data,   relapse_data,   initiation_data,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities ‚Äî quit_est
text: trend_data Data table containing statistically model trends current, former never smoking output trend_fit(). survivorship_data Data table containing estimates cohort survivorship age, sex IMD quintile. output prep_surv(). mortality_data Data table containing estimated age-specific probabilities death smoking status. output smoke_surv(). relapse_data Data table containing estimates long-term relapse probabilities. output prep_relapse(). initiation_data Data table containing estimates initiation probabilities age, cohort, sex IMD quintile. output init_adj(). min_age Integer - youngest age considered. max_age Integer - oldest age considered. min_year Integer - earliest year observed data. max_year Integer - latest year observed data.

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities ‚Äî quit_est
text: Returns data.table containing estimated quit probabilities.

title: Estimate smoking quit probabilities ‚Äî quit_est
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  ## SMOKING INITIATION  # Calculate the cumulative probabilities of starting to smoke for each cohort init_data_raw <- smktrans::init_est(  data = hse_data,  strat_vars = c("sex", "imd_quintile") )  # Estimate the trends in ever-smoking ever_smoke_data <- smktrans::ever_smoke(   data = hse_data,   time_horizon = 2200,   num_bins = 7,   model = "England" )  # Adjust and forecast init_data_adj <- init_adj(   init_data = copy(init_data_raw),   ever_smoke_data = copy(ever_smoke_data$predicted_values),   ref_age = 30,   cohorts = 1971:2100,   period_start = 2001, period_end = 2016)  # Convert the probabilities of ever-smoking to # age-specific probabilities of smoking initiation smk_init_data <- p_dense(data = copy(init_data_adj),   cum_func_var = "p_ever_smoker_adj",   strat_vars = c("cohort", "sex", "imd_quintile"))   ## SMOKING QUIT  # Fit multinomial model to trends in proportion of current, former and never smokers trend_data <- smktrans::trend_fit(hse_data,    max_iterations = 1e3,    age_var = "age",    year_var = "year",    sex_var = "sex",    smoker_state_var = "smk.state",    imd_var = "imd_quintile",    weight_var = "wt_int")  # Estimate cohort survivorship stratified by age, sex and IMD quintile survivorship_data <- smktrans::prep_surv(   mx_data_hmd = smktrans::hmd_data,   mx_data_ons = smktrans::tob_mort_data )  # Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status mortality_data <- smktrans::smoke_surv(   data = hse_data,   diseases  = unique(tobalcepi::tobacco_relative_risks$condition),   mx_data = stapmr::tob_mort_data_cause )  # Prepare probabilities of long-term relapse relapse_data <- smktrans::prep_relapse(   data = hse_data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse,   lowest_year = 2001,   highest_year = 2016,   youngest_age = 11 )  # Estimate the quit probabilities quit_data <- quit_est(   trend_data = copy(trend_data),   survivorship_data = copy(survivorship_data),   mortality_data = copy(mortality_data$data_for_quit_ests),   relapse_data = copy(relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd),   initiation_data = copy(init_data_final) )  } # }

what: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
text: Forecasts period trends probabilities smoking initiation, quitting relapse age, sex IMD quintile. function designed originally forecast just probabilities quitting since extended forecast initiation relapse probabilities .

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
code: quit_forecast(   data,   forecast_var,   forecast_type = c("continuing", "stationary"),   cont_limit = NULL,   oldest_year = 2003,   youngest_age = 11,   oldest_age = 88,   age_cont_limit = 88,   first_year = 2010,   jump_off_year = 2015,   time_horizon = 2050,   smooth_rate_dim = c(3, 3),   k_smooth_age = 3 )

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
text: data Data table containing probabilities forecast. forecast_var Character - name probability variable forecast. forecast_type Character - whether apply estimated rates proportional change ("continuing") keep forecast variable constant last observed value ("stationary"). cont_limit Integer - year continuing forecast becomes stationary. oldest_year Integer - oldest year data . Default set 2003 England. youngest_age Integer - youngest age data. Default set 11 England. oldest_age Integer - oldest age data - set 88 quitting relapse 30 initiation. age_cont_limit Integer - age forecast transition probabilities year, sex IMD quintile assumed change. first_year Integer - earliest year data forecast based. jump_off_year Integer - last year data. time_horizon Integer - last year forecast period. smooth_rate_dim Numeric vector length 2. dimensions 2d window used smooth trends rates age year. (age, year), Defaults c(3, 3). Must odd numbers. k_smooth_age Integer - degree smoothing apply age pattern change (rotation). zero, smoothing applied.

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
text: Returns data.table containing observed forecast data.

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
text: forecast based applying Singular value decomposition (SVD) logit transformed matrix quit probabilities age year subgroup.

title: Forecast probabilities of smoking initiation, quitting and relapse ‚Äî quit_forecast
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  forecast_data <- quit_forecast(   data = copy(quit_data),   forecast_var = "quit_prob",   forecast_type = "continuing",   first_year = 2010,   jump_off_year = 2015,   time_horizon = 2030 )  } # }

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
text: Produces future projections annual probabilities relapse former smokers, stratified age, sex, IMD quintile number years since quitting (10 years).

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
code: relapse_forecast(   relapse_forecast_data,   relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit,   jump_off_year = 2018 )

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
text: relapse_forecast_data Data table - output quit_forecast(). relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit Data table - output prep_relapse() relapse probabilities stratified age, sex, IMD quintile time since quitting. jump_off_year integer - last year observed data.

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
text: Returns data.table past future relapse probabilities stratified age, sex, IMD quintile time since quitting.

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
text: difficult reliably forecast values stratified age, sex, IMD quintile time since quitting due high dimensionality data. therefore forecast values stratified age, sex IMD quintile, forecasts calculate scaling values applied relapse probabilities estimated last year observed data produce forecasts stratified age, sex, IMD quintile time since quitting.

title: Forecast relapse probabilities ‚Äî relapse_forecast
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # Combine published estimates of long-term relapse with  # the Health Survey for England data to arrive at the expected values  # for relapse probabilities within defined subgroups. relapse_data <- smktrans::prep_relapse(   data = hse_data,   hawkins_relapse = smktrans::hawkins_relapse,   lowest_year = 2001,   highest_year = 2018,   youngest_age = 11 )  # Forecasting relapse probabilities is tricky because  # the probabilities that are used in the model are stratified by age, sex, IMDq and time since quitting # The approach will be to forecast the version of the probabilities stratified by age, sex and IMDq only # and then use the results to scale the higher dimensional version  relapse_forecast_data <- quit_forecast(   data = copy(relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd),   forecast_var = "p_relapse",   forecast_type = "continuing", # continuing or stationary   cont_limit = 2030, # the year at which the forecast becomes stationary   first_year = 2001, # the earliest year of data on which the forecast is based   jump_off_year = 2018,   time_horizon = 2100 )  # plot to check relapse_forecast_plot <- ggplot(relapse_forecast_data[age == 50 & year <= 2030]) +   geom_line(aes(x = year, y = p_relapse, colour = imd_quintile)) +   facet_wrap(~ sex) +   theme_minimal() +   ylab("P(relapse)") +    #ylim(0, 1) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 2018, linetype = 2)  relapse_forecast_plot  test_data <- relapse_forecast(   relapse_forecast_data = relapse_forecast_data,   relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit = relapse_data$relapse_by_age_imd_timesincequit,   jump_off_year = 2018 ) } # }

what: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data ‚Äî smktrans-package
title: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data ‚Äî smktrans-package
text: Estimates probabilities individuals initiate, quit relapse regular cigarette smoking cross-sectional survey data.

title: smktrans: smktrans: An R Package for estimating smoking state transition probabilities from cross-sectional survey data ‚Äî smktrans-package
text: Maintainer: Duncan Gillespie duncan.gillespie@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID) Authors: Laura Webster (ORCID) Grace Leeming g.leeming@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID) Magdalena Opazo-Breton Alan Brennan .brennan@sheffield.ac.uk (ORCID)

what: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
text: Estimates probability individual survive beginning end year interval different probabilities survival depending individuals smoking status probability survival former smokers adjusted according estimates risk declines time since quit.

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
code: smoke_surv(   data,   diseases = tobalcepi::tob_disease_names,   mx_data,   min_age = 11,   max_age = 89,   min_year = 2003,   max_year = 2018 )

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
text: data Data table individual characteristics, including age, sex, IMD quintile smoking status. diseases Character vector smoking related conditions. mx_data Data table containing cause-specific rates death smoking related diseases. min_age Integer - youngest age considered. max_age Integer - oldest age considered. min_year Integer - earliest year observed data. max_year Integer - latest year observed data.

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
text: Returns two data tables containing age-specific probabilities death survival 1 year age interval, stratified sex, year, imd_quintile smoking state. One data table detailed estimates tidied form needed quit probability estimation.

title: Estimate age-specific probabilities of death by smoking status ‚Äî smoke_surv
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  test_data <- smoke_surv(   data = hse_data,   diseases  = tobalcepi::tob_disease_names,   mx_data = tob_mort_data_cause )  } # }

what: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
text: Fit multinomial model distribution people among current, former never smoking status estimate variation trends sex socioeconomic conditions terms quintiles Index Multiple Deprivation. parameterisation statistical model within function can strong effect estimated probabilities quitting smoking trajectories smoking prevalence forecast using estimates.

title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
code: trend_fit(   data,   max_iterations = 1000,   age_var = "age",   year_var = "year",   sex_var = "sex",   smoker_state_var = "smk.state",   imd_var = "imd_quintile",   weight_var = "wt_int" )

title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
text: data Data table containing individual-level survey data multiple years. max_iterations Integer - maximum number iterations try looking multinomial model converge stable model fit. age_var Character - name variable containing age single years. year_var Character - name variable containing year single years. sex_var Character - name variable containing sex (m/f). smoker_state_var Character - name variable containing smoking status (current, former, never smoker). imd_var Character - name variable containing Index Multiple Deprivation quintiles. weight_var Character - name variable containing survey weights.

title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
text: Returns data table containing fitted values age, year, sex IMD quintile.

title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
text: explanatory variables age year specified form cubic response surface. additional 4th order term age added better capture non-linear patterns age e.g. individuals initiate quit age. Interactions surface sex IMD quintiles limited 3rd order terms. Interactions quadratic term included age year avoid -fitting variation trend years, linear change pattern age. decision made visually exploring fit simpler complex model specifications data.

title: Statistically model trends in current, former and never smoking ‚Äî trend_fit
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  test_data <- trend_fit(data = hse_data)  } # }
